title: Authors and Citation

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cutler J (2025). jamesmisc: Package Miscellaneous Functions Analytics Probability. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {jamesmisc: A Package of Miscellaneous Functions for Analytics and Probability},   author = {James Cutler},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

what: A Package of Miscellaneous Functions for Analytics and Probability
title: A Package of Miscellaneous Functions for Analytics and Probability
text: Welcome friends! homepage R package handful miscellaneous functions. Hopefully functions useful well. includes annuity_n_rates(), can calculate display growth curves investment (say, retirement plan), fixed annual contributions, different annual rates growth: Unfortunately, plot output isn’t visible README, visible function reference page!  includes binomial_dist() want compute visualize probability event binomial experiment. example, apply 8 schools, acceptance rate 20%, probability get least one ? (, plot output isn’t visible README, visible function reference page!)  , 55 people received particular surgery followed see later regretted . Zero regretted . expecting 5% regret , assumption probability zero end regretting ? (Also, visible README, plot visible function reference page.)  includes check_normality() want quickly assess normality variable qq-plot, Shapiro-Wilk test normality, also visualize distribution variable histogram normal curve super-imposed: (Plots visible corresponding function reference page.)   also plot_logistic_results() plotting adjusted odds ratios 95% CI multivariable logistic regression analysis: (Plot can viewed function reference page.)  ’s strat_proportion_plot(), plotting counts percentages categorical variable stratified another categorical variable, dataset: (Plot can viewed function reference page.)  ’s function, taxes(), getting sense net income , given gross income. calculates federal state taxes live California Oklahoma. married filing jointly. Sorry, ’s now. dinky little functions well. Enjoy!
code: library(jamesmisc)  list_data_and_plot <- annuity_n_returns(   initial_investment = 20000, # The initial investment   annuity = 10000,            # The annual contribution, starting the year after the initial investment   years = 30,                 # The time over which the investment grows   return_rates = c(.06,.07,.08,.09,.1) # The annual return rates to visually compare (.06 = 6% annual return) ) list_data_and_plot[[1]] # 8 schools; 20% chance of success (acceptance) for each; at least one acceptance means include the possibility of 1 success and every possibility of a higher number of successes, up to 8 (so) binomial_dist(   n_trials = 8,            # 8 is the number of "trials" in the binomial experiment   prob = .20,              # 20% is the chance of success for each trial   tail_cutoff = 1,         # 1 success is where the tail/portion of the distribution representing the 'event' stops   left_or_right = "right"  # It's the right tail/portion of the distribution (every possibility >= 1 success) ) # 55 people get the surgery; it was expected beforehand that 5% would regret the surgery; zero people actually ended up regretting it; zero "or less" is the tail/portion of the binomial distribution that we're interested in, then--so, the left tail. binomial_dist(55,.05,0,"left") # Assess whether chicken weight, in the ChickWeight dataset, is approximately normally distributed check_normality(ChickWeight,"weight") Shapiro-Wilk normality test  data:  myvar W = 0.90866, p-value < 2.2e-16 library(dplyr) Attaching package: 'dplyr'  The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':      filter, lag  The following objects are masked from 'package:base':      intersect, setdiff, setequal, union # Let's model survival in the Titanic disaster by regressing it on sex, age group (child/adult), and class.  data("Titanic")  titanic_tbl <- Titanic %>%   tibble::as_tibble() %>%   tidyr::uncount(n) %>%   mutate(     Survived = factor(Survived,levels = c("Yes","No")) %>% as.numeric(),     Survived = Survived - 1,     Survived = factor(Survived)   )  titanic_fit <- glm(   Survived ~ Sex + Age + Class,   data = titanic_tbl,   family = binomial )  # Visualize the adjusted odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals in a dot-whisker plot plot_logistic_results(   titanic_fit,   subtitle = "Relative odds of not surviving the Titanic (compared to reference group)",   log_scale = FALSE # The default is TRUE (set the x axis to a log scale rather than linear scale) ) Scale for x is already present. Adding another scale for x, which will replace the existing scale. # Visualize counts and percentages of the engines with different numbers of cylinders, stratified by transmission strat_proportion_plot(   data    = mtcars, # Your dataset   row_var = cyl,    # The 'row' variable in your dataset: In this case, number of cylinders (4, 6, or 8)   col_var = am,     # The 'column' variable in your dataset: In this case, transmission type (stick or automatic - 1 or 0)   x_label = "Cylinder",   plot_title = "Number of cylinders (count, %), stratified by transmission type" ) taxes(   80000,            # e.g., $80,000 gross income   state_name = "OK" # Can switch to 'CA' for California ) %>% glimpse() Rows: 1 Columns: 10 $ Gross_Income       <dbl> 80000 $ Tax_Filing         <chr> "Married" $ Fed_Top_Marginal   <chr> "0.12, 19901, 0.751" $ State_Top_Marginal <chr> "0.0525, 15001, 0.812" $ Fed_Taxes          <dbl> 9201.88 $ State_Taxes        <dbl> 3807.297 $ SocialSec_Medicare <chr> "4960, 1160" $ Prop_Taken         <dbl> 0.2391147 $ Net_Income         <dbl> 60870.82 $ If_No_State_Tax    <dbl> 64678.12

what: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity
title: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity
text: function takes initial investment amount, amount annuities added investment every year, annual return rate, years investment, returns numeric vector representing new amount every year.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity
code: annuity(return_rate, initial_investment, annuity, years)

title: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity
text: return_rate numeric representing annual return rate. initial_investment numeric representing initial investment amount. annuity numeric representing amount added investment every year. years numeric representing number years investment period.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity
text: numeric vector representing size investment year.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities — annuity

what: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns
title: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns
text: function takes initial investment amount, amount annuities added investment every year, vector annual return rates, years investment, returns interactive plot displaying performance various return rates specified period, well tibble data displayed plot.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns
code: annuity_n_returns(   initial_investment,   annuity,   years,   return_rates = c(0.06, 0.07, 0.08, 0.09, 0.1) )

title: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns
text: initial_investment numeric representing initial investment amount. annuity numeric representing amount added investment every year. years numeric representing number years investment period. return_rates numeric vector representing specified annual return rates.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns
text: list : 1) plotly plot object displaying growth curves various investments, 2) tibble containing data displayed plot.

title: Compute investment growth with annuities for a variety of annual return rates — annuity_n_returns

what: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist
title: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist
text: function takes parameters binomial experiment (n trials, probability success) tail cutoff point tail distribution represents event want know probability (event consisting range values number successes), plots distribution portion corresponding event filled .

title: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist
code: binomial_dist(n_trials, prob, tail_cutoff, left_or_right)

title: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist
text: n_trials non-zero integer representing number Bernoulli trials experiment. prob numeric value representing probability success trial. Range: 0 1. tail_cutoff integer representing cutoff point number successes. right left cutoff (inclusive) desired range portion distribution corresponds event interest. left_or_right character indicating whether event interest corresponds possible range successes right left cutoff point. Possible values: c("left", "right").

title: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist
text: interactive plotly plot specified binomial distribution, portion distribution colored represent event interest, probability event plot title.

title: Plot the distribution of a specified binomial random variable, with probability of specified event — binomial_dist

what: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
title: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
text: function takes data frame string variable name wish assess normality, outputs QQ plot, histogram superimposed normal curve, results Shapiro-Wilk test.

title: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
code: check_normality(data, variable_name, just_qqplot = F, just_shapiro_pval = F)

title: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
text: data data frame variable interest. variable_name character; name variable interest. variable's sample size must 3 5,000, inclusive. just_qqplot logical; want just qqplot? TRUE/FALSE. Default FALSE. just_shapiro_pval logical; want just Shapiro-Wilk p-value? TRUE/FALSE. Default FALSE.

title: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
text: qqplot, histogram variable's distribution normal curve superimposed, results Shapiro-Wilk test.

title: Asses normality using a QQ plot, a histogram with normal density curve superimposed, and a Shapiro-Wilk test for normality — check_normality
code: # Assess the normality of mpg in mtcars check_normality(ChickWeight,"weight")   #>  #> 	Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  myvar #> W = 0.90866, p-value < 2.2e-16 #>

what: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
title: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
text: function takes annual return rate, initial investment amount, number years accrued interest, returns terminal amount end specified period.

title: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
code: interest(return_rate, initial_investment, years)

title: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
text: return_rate numeric representing annual return rate. negative value indicate decay rate. initial_investment numeric representing initial amount invested. years numeric representing number years initial investment grows specified return rate.

title: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
text: numeric representing terminal amount, accruing specified interest specified period.

title: Compute exponential growth or decay / compute compound interest — interest
code: # How much will you have after 30 years of an intial $10,000 growing at 7% per year? interest(.07,10000,30) #> [1] 76122.55

what: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
title: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
text: function takes glm object (multivariable logistic regression model) returns ggplot estimated adjusted odds ratios covariate, corresponding 95% confidence intervals.

title: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
code: plot_logistic_results(   model,   title = "Adjusted Odds Ratios with 95% CI",   subtitle = NULL,   log_scale = TRUE )

title: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
text: model fitted glm model. title character, default set 'Adjusted Odds Ratios 95% CI'. subtitle character. Default NULL. log_scale logical. like see odds ratios log scale? TRUE/FALSE. Default TRUE.

title: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
text: dot-whisker plot estimated adjusted odds ratios 95% confidence intervals.

title: Dot-whisker plot of odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals from a multivariable logistic regression model — plot_logistic_results
code: # Visualize the relative odds of not surviving the Titanic # E.g., For males vs. females, after adjusting for class and age group library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  data("Titanic")  titanic_tbl <- Titanic %>% tibble::as_tibble() %>% tidyr::uncount(n) %>% mutate(   Survived = factor(Survived,levels = c("Yes","No")) %>% as.numeric(),   Survived = Survived - 1,   Survived = factor(Survived)  )  titanic_fit <- glm(Survived ~ Sex + Age + Class,data = titanic_tbl,family = binomial)  plot_logistic_results( titanic_fit, subtitle = "Relative odds of not surviving the Titanic" )

what: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols
title: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols
text: function takes data frame automatically removes columns contain NA values. Also, user can set desired threshold removing columns proportion NA values exceeding threshold.

title: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols
code: remove_na_cols(data, threshold = 1)

title: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols
text: data data frame tibble. NA-columns, removed, though necessary data NA-columns. threshold numeric 0 1. Default 1 (.e., 100%). Represents threshold proportion NA values user wants remove columns purely NA, whose proportion NA values exceeds specified threshold.

title: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols
text: data frame, minus columns removed

title: Remove columns in a data frame that only have NA values (or that exceed a specified proportion of NA values) — remove_na_cols

what: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
title: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
text: function takes data frame, categorical row variable, categorical column variable, plots proportions row variable categories stratified (faceted ) column variable categories. Error bars represent 95% confidence intervals proportions.

title: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
code: strat_proportion_plot(   data,   row_var,   col_var,   x_label = "Row Variable",   plot_title = "Stratified Counts and Percentages" )

title: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
text: data data frame. row_var categorical row variable (passed string). col_var categorical column variable (passed string). counts percents row variable stratified column variable. x_label character. X axis label. plot_title character. plot title.

title: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
text: ggplot stratified proportions CI errorbars

title: Plot bivariate proportions with confidence intervals — strat_proportion_plot
code: # Plot of counts and % of cylinder categories stratified by transmission category in mtcars strat_proportion_plot(mtcars,cyl,am,"Cylinder","Number of cylinders (count, %) by transmission type")

what: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
title: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
text: function takes numeric value representing gross income returns tibble information like net income, amount pay federal taxes state taxes (possible states Oklahoma California), things. Married filing jointly assumed.

title: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
code: taxes(gross_income, state_name = "OK")

title: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
text: gross_income numeric positive value representing gross annual income. state_name character. 'OK' Oklahoma, 'CA' California. Default 'OK'.

title: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
text: tibble following things: federal top marginal rate, state top marginal rate, federal taxes, state taxes, amount paid social security medicare, proportion removed gross income, net income, net income state taxes.

title: Compute your net income from your gross income, after factoring in federal and state taxes — taxes
code: # What is your net income in Oklahoma if your gross income is $80,000? taxes(80000) #> # A tibble: 1 × 10 #>   Gross_Income Tax_Filing Fed_Top_Marginal   State_Top_Marginal   Fed_Taxes #>          <dbl> <chr>      <chr>              <chr>                    <dbl> #> 1        80000 Married    0.12, 19901, 0.751 0.0525, 15001, 0.812     9202. #> # ℹ 5 more variables: State_Taxes <dbl>, SocialSec_Medicare <chr>, #> #   Prop_Taken <dbl>, Net_Income <dbl>, If_No_State_Tax <dbl>
